title: What does an Ontology Engineering Community look like? A Systematic Analysis of the Schema.org Community
segmentation: Hi, I'm Sammy and I'm going to be talking to you about our analysis of the schema.org community.
So a bit of background and motivation.
So I'm creating authority is a really complicated process.
You don't just need the technical skills, you also need the domain expertise for the for the area of the ontology you're creating.
So I think it's quite unsurprising the ontology engineering has become a very collaborative endeavour with interdisciplinary teams of.
Domain experts and technical experts both working together to create these ontologies.
So in light of that, quite a few ontology and collaborative ontology engineering tools have been created.
And those tools themselves and how they used to create the ontologies have been studied in previous literature.
But what we're still actually lacking is the study of the communities behind that.
Though the discussions, the processes, and the ways things run behind the scene to collaboratively create ontologies.

So because of that we decided to analyzeaschema.org community, one of the largest and most relevant ontology engineering communities, both to see how these communities work and if there's any suggestions we could make for future improvements.
So.
I'm sorry again.
As I said previously, in existing literature there is quite a few studies on the ontology editing tools themselves, so how the tools are used?
People have done case studies, an changelog, studies to look at the different roles, or the users.
Taking editing ontologies to try and predict where people are going to make changes.

I think one of the papers for prediction of changes was quite amusing because it said we've made some success in prediction, but we need to do some more work on it and Gale ET al actually looked at 230 semantic mediawiki's.

And they found that only a really small subset of users end up creating the properties and walk ended up identifying a bunch of roles of ontology engineering which we Endologix editing, which I'll go over later because they informed our work and some of the roles we've looked up.
But all of this work is actually done in the frame of ontology engineering rather than the community behind it.
So there is a sort of clear gap for our research here.
I'm.
So we also know that we're looking at community.
We're not just looking at the peer technical notion of ontology engineering, so we need to think about other communication platforms as well as just the ontology editing tools.
We know.
The schema doggies GitHub as one of their main communication platform, so we had a bit of a lecture lecture on GitHub as well.
What we found is that.

Yeah, there has been some work done on linking GitHub to ontology editing, but again very much in the frame of just what changes are made, what edits are made rather than how that process, how those processes are formed.
Our research is also showing the platforms like GitHub have quite complex social structures, so users have profiles you can go on a user's profile.
You can see what they've coded.
You can get an idea of their skills and we're going to pass in there, and whether you want to work with them before you even had a conversation with them.
And similarly, users can look at group projects.
They can see the commits, they can see the code, they can see the discussions.
And they can form an idea of, you know how much work a group might entail, or whether they actually want to get involved with the group or not.
So it's these things aren't simple, which is why we've kind of taken a more qualitative approach to start this off and to look at the Community aspects.
So bear in mind we then decided to look at our four main research themes based on the literature we've looked at and we know that these factors impact the ontologies that are created.
So we've chosen to look at topic prevalence.
So this is what are the main topics coming out of this and therefore all the different groups that they're using being used as their expected?
Are they being used with the appropriate material?
Also popular topic.
So what topics do users engage with most?
How does this impact on the community and?
Again, are there areas that really aren't being engaged with that should be at their suggestions.
We can make to make things better.
Also participation distribution.
So generally studies of online communities have shown that they tend to follow their 99.
One rule, which is where they are only 10% of the users perform 90% of the work.
So we've looked at whetherschema.org fits into that pattern or not.
And then finally, we've tried to identify some typical user profiles based on our participation, distribution, work.
So this is just a kind of rough workflow if you will, of how schema.org works.
They've got three main groups, the first groups, the one at the top.
That's the steering group.
That's quite a small group that's just for the high level members, and that's where they basically organize the agendas for when they're going to discuss the releases.
But there are actually very few posts and communications around that.
And then you've got your two main groups, which is a community group on the GitHub group, so the Community group.
I mean, they say the purpose is for sort of day-to-day discussions and liaising about functionality.
It's a W3C group, but he's got a public mailing list.
Anyone can jump in and get involved with different topics.
And then you've also got GitHub and that she used for discussion, new functionality, raising issues where things are broken or raising issues for new extensions.
So we took a mixed methods approach to doing this, so the topic prevalence is very much done through qualitative analysis, so we did iterative thematic coding.
So that's where you actually let the themes come out of the data.
Mostly, rather than going into it with a preset themes and see where things fall into that.

And then we use some more concrete methods to compute the rest of the numbers, and I wrote a few Python scripts to pull the numbers out of the GitHub API for all the GitHub starts, and then we would just say I just had to pull all the email ones off the public mailing list.
So firstly, this is the topic prevalence, so the methods we used here as that iterative thematic coding.
So walk identified four different roles.

Which we've ended up making into the modification extension organization an bug, so these were actually rolls with ontology editing themselves, but we figured you know this is about making it a story.
This is about where people are raising discussions about editing the ontology, so we picked those other ones in green.
And then we went through all the GitHub issues 1st and we ended up coming up with the next 6.
7 The Note 66 are written in blue, shouldn't you similar colors and slides?

And they directly came out of the data and then we also ended up adding a really off other off topic one for anything that didn't fit into our categories 'cause there's always going to be an online community, something that's not appropriate or that doesn't fit into any of the categories.
So we wanted to add that.

We then discussed, or we then really formally discussed the categories so that we know exactly what we were talking about, and we formalized the definition, so they're the ones were up on the slides and they were in the paper.
And then when we created the emails, we end up adding a topic of release because it became.

That was another really obvious theme that emerged because in the emails they actually specifically talked about when they were going to schedule releases, whereas that was something that didn't occur on the GitHub side of things.

So for the topic popularity, we computed a bunch of statistics essentially, so we looked at the number of email threads about a topic, the number of GitHub issues about a topic, and then the subsequent replies to a thread or comments on a thread about those topics.
We also looked at the meaning medium responses to see because some topics had a lot more popularity than others.

We also looked at where things have gone unanswered, and then we also computed a random 10% of the unanswered ones just so we could try and get an idea of why they weren't answered and whether that you know.
There was actually perfectly valid reasons for not answering them or whether they were areas where we weren't sure why they weren't being answered.
For party

Patient distribution we define participation by the number of emails you've started, the number of emails you've replied to, and then similarly the number of issues you've starred on GitHub and the number of issues you've replied to.

So those were our metrics for participation, distribution, and we also looked at the top 10% of users across both both different groups to see what the overlap was and to see if there was some clear leaders.
I'm.
From our participation distribution because our main metrics we're looking at discussions replied to and started.
We use those to identify are different types of user profiles.

So for the results for the topic prevalence, the main thing we found was that the Community group really focuses on clarification an extension, so that is, you know, am I using this term in the right way?
Is this what it's meant to do or does this exist even?
Or we think we need this new functionality with some on the organizational side of things?
Because as you know is used more for the Community group is as carbon organizational feel to it, whereas GitHub was very much focused on modification and extension.
So changing existing functionality and adding new functionality with some focus on clarification.
And then, perhaps unsurprisingly, the topic popularity very much reflected the topic prevalence, so.
See if you can.
I hoping you guys can see this graph and you can see the colors, but less blue is a good thing basically.
But again, this is very much reflected, so if you can see the topic for the Community group which is on the left hand side, again the extension in the clarification are pretty popular.
And then for GitHub you've got extension again and modification.
So these kind of.

These reflect this, but then in itself that kind of shows that actually because there's so many more topics on there, so many more posts and comments about some topics that then maybe it's kind of follow through that they would get the most responses so.
But so then, we also looked at the medium medium responses and where there are no replies.
So from what we can see here, the response level varies really significantly and the median is typically lower or similar than the mean for the Community group rose.
It's always lower for GitHub and actually we end up with over 50% of thread started or issues started getting less two or less than comments.
So even though there's some with you at later comments, there's quite a huge variety in this response, so clearly we need to stop dig deeper into these issues and why.

So we also computed as we gotta be, to completely random 10% sample of both the emails on the GitHub post to see why we weren't getting these responses and actually it was quite comforting to an extent because for the for the emails you know somewhere we continued on GitHub because they'd raised an issue and then they continue to have the discussion on GitHub, so there was no reason to continue with the email somewhere.
Just spam so you know if someone says unsubscribe before we get unsubscribed and not reply to them, or if it's Pam, you're probably not gonna reply to them.
Some ended up just they didn't really matter apply, so is actually quite low level of emails where we weren't sure why they weren't getting replies.
On GitHub there were more that didn't get replies, but they were all quite relatively knew, so we figured there must just be a response time lag.
And again, that's something we would look into in future work.
And some were just someone would create an issue and then assign it to themselves.
So again, no one else really needs to get involved or you've ended up with some issues where multiple issues reference the same thing.
And I think people end up just converging to that issue that has a bigger discussion on it.
And then again, so I'm just really didn't matter apply.
So Wolf, there are quite a lot of errors.
Aren't getting replies.
We can also see that there's quite a lot of reasonable reasons why, so again, this will kind of involve further digging into then see which bits are getting replies.
It need to get replies.
So this is our participation distribution.
So along the top, we're looking at the people starting the conversation, so starting email threads, raising issues down the left.
We're going at the email, so you've got email sent at the top and he replies at the bottom and then kind of along the bottom.
You've got the replies, so we pointed out like that.
There were quite a lot more GitHub like I unique users than there were for the community groups almost double, but you can see there's quite a few patterns on these graphs.
So for a start at the bottom, so that's where there's responses.

There's a much higher level of response generally than there is initially starting the conversations, and then there's also really obviously one sort of one, or in some cases a few very peak users, and then you've got kind of a set of medium level users, and then it just completely tails off to 0.
So we then also elect at the top ten 10 users.
So we've aligned users where possible here, so where we've seen there using, you know the same email address, same name.
We've link them together, so we know that the same person.
Unfortunately, we know that's not.

We can't guarantee we did that perfectly because some people use incredibly different handles on GitHub to their name, so if you if there were ones that weren't obvious, we only actually linked were very sure it was the same person.

But if you think there are essentially 40 slots here to be the top person sending emails, the top person replying to emails, sending starting GitHub issues and replying, there's only actually 19 users filling those 14 slots and the person at the top for each one is the same user and we were able to link that together quite obviously.
So again, this kind of does to an extent fall in with that 99 one rule, although actually for it.
For this it's more like 10% of the users do 80% of the work rather than 90%, but it does follow through with that a bit.
So then we also identified are typical user profiles, so we've got leaders was about 10% of those across the groups.
So these are the ones that very much the ones we sort of the graphs reach so that they actively start discussions.
But they also actively reply to discussions.
There very involved both ways.

You don't kind of got the people in the middle, so the broadcasters, so they tend to start a lot of discussions, but they don't necessarily apply to other peoples then similarly you've got the followers, so they might not want to raise issues themselves within their very happy to reply to other people once in issues been raised.
And then you've got our largest ones.
So over 75% of both groups were lurkers.
So they might comment on one.
Yeah, we know that there we part with him as our users, 'cause they've commented on one thing here or there, but they've they actually have very little.
In fact, because they don't reply to discussions and they don't start discussions and so therefore we don't really have much of my dear how they're engaging.
Apart from that, we know they're there watching.
So overall findings are that are the topic prevalence.

GitHub is much more used for like make making changes or we edit existing functionality or adding extensions that are topic popularity very much reflects our topic prevalence, so maybe that to an extent is a self fulfilling prophecy but.
And the participation distribution is less unequal than we expected.
So again, 10% of the users are doing about 80% of the work, so it's nice that it's less unequal than we thought it was going to be.
Majority of our users were lurkers on both platforms.
So we are aware that we had some limitations to this study.
This was a very initial study, very like.
First study so matching users between the platforms wasn't an exact science we I can't guarantee that there weren't people we didn't miss.
If they had really different GitHub handles to email, so there might be a few stats that we haven't got correct here.
We have done some pretty qualitative analysis on the theme, so these are the ones we came out with.
Maybe other people would have come out with different things.
So maybe in future work it be worth having much wider groups working on this together.
We know we haven't considered all engagement types.
We've currently very much stuck to the basics for this first study, and you know, we know we could expand our analysis.
But kind of on that note for future work.
We think some of the things that we really interesting to go forward with calculating the number of extensions suggested by new users that actually get incorporated in.
So we know that we have the schematics quite a welcoming community.
People can come in, they can jump in anytime and people can propose new functionality.
So it be nice and so would be nice to see to try and follow those trails or where someone said oh, actually, there's a need for this.
How many of them make it into the releases?
How many of them are accepted?
You know and actually follow through, and if so, why?
Why does I'm not get follow through so that would be a really interesting area to look at.
Also, the influence of social standing in the social dynamics.
So is one of the leaders.
If they suggest something and they're like we should do this or they aren't getting an idea how much impact does that actually have?
Also, the adoption of engagement overtime.
So if someone starts, you know, jumps into the middle has an email, makes a comment at what point do they then move, but me for maybe a lurker to a follower, or even to a leader.
You know where, how?
What's that time frame and how long does it take?
How many users actually do that?
That would be really interesting to look up.
And finally also just the way issues get solved I think would be really interesting to look out.
So how many get self assigned?
Who actually gets assigned issues?
And what's that process?
So that's all for me.
Thank you very much for listening, and sorry about the hiccup with slides at the beginning.
Any questions?
